bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Michael E. Connor, [19--]

div1.p: [Carter] sends Connor a historical epidemiological study of yellow fever in Mexico and Central America for his comments.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Michael E. Connor, [19--]
div1.opener:
Book
/LC
Same (about) Hanson Ha Connor
S
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Doctor Connor:
div1.p:
Nearly a month ago I sent the I. H. B. one Section of the work I
am engaged on--namely, The Epidemiology of Yellow Fever. This was to
have been mimeographed and sent out to the field men. I hope then you
will have received it before--or at the time--you get this this enclos-
ure, because it should be taken first.

What I am sending you now is an historico-epidemiological study
of the occurrence of yellow fever in Mexico and Central America at the
of and prior to the Conquest, on which I would be glad to have your
judgment, and Scannell's if he be with you.

When I commenced this study--a little over a year ago--I was clear-
ly of the opinion that yellow fever was indigenous to America and had
been carried to Africa therefrom. Until I complete my study of the
Carib area I cannot eliminate America--nor have I made sufficient inqui-
ry into the early (Portuguese) reports of the West Coast to incriminate
Africa, but, frankly, I do feel like excusing Mexico and Yucatan.
